item.title: Larian‚Äôs AI Use Has Even Baldur‚Äôs Gate 3 Diehards Speaking Out
item.content:encoded:
Today, Bloomberg posted an interview with Larian Studios CEO Swen Vincke in which he explained that the Baldur‚Äôs Gate 3 and Divinity developer has started integrating generative AI into its workflow. This is being used for PowerPoint presentations, placeholder text, and concept art, and according to Vincke, ‚Äúeveryone at the company is more or less OK with the way [Larian is] using it.‚Äù Despite Vincke‚Äôs best efforts to contextualize the ways in which the technology is being used and his promise that no genAI would make its way into the finished product, many fans are not happy, and the statements have generated a massive backlash on social media.

In the past few years, Larian has made a name for itself as a staunchly pro-human game developer. Baldur‚Äôs Gate 3 won Game of the Year at the Game Awards, and Vincke himself gave an impassioned speech at the 2024 ceremony about how future GOTY winners would be games that didn‚Äôt ‚Äútreat their developers like numbers on a spreadsheet‚Äù and would be made by people who ‚Äúknew that if you put the game and the team first, the revenue will follow.‚Äù So, as you can expect, hearing that the studio has started using AI to generate concept art and ideas has felt to some like a mask drop moment for a studio that has been so publicly supportive of human creativity.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=YvRm4HKK4gQ

Vincke went on to clarify his comments in a statement to IGN, saying this technology is meant to be ‚Äúadditive to a creative team or individual‚Äôs workflow, not a replacement for their skill or craft.‚Äù He also doubled down on his assertion that Larian will not include generated assets in its upcoming turn-based RPG Divinity when it launches in a few years. But even if Vincke says the final product won‚Äôt have anything produced by AI in it, the fact that this technology is being integrated at a studio whose greatest accomplishments have come from human creativity is worrying to many, and has brought some folks‚Äô excitement for Divinity to a screeching halt just days after its announcement at last week‚Äôs Game Awards.

item.title: Damn, The Outer Worlds 2‚Äòs Flaw System Is So Good
item.content:encoded:
I was nearly 30 hours into The Outer Worlds 2 when I lied to a character during a conversation. A few moments later, a message popped up on my screen. I had lied enough times, apparently, that I was offered the chance to take a new secret trait that would force me to lie whenever possible, but I could do so perfectly. This is the Flaws System, and it‚Äôs one of my favorite features in a game I‚Äôve played this year.

Released earlier this year, The Outer Worlds 2 is Obsidian‚Äôs bigger and better open-world RPG sequel to 2019‚Äôs The Outer Worlds. If the first game was a fun attempt at recreating Bethesda‚Äôs Fallout formula, The Outer Worlds 2 is the studio nailing it. In fact, I think in some ways the team has beaten Bethesda at its own game, with improved writing, better combat, and some other cool ideas, like Flaws.

Technically, Flaws were a feature in the first Outer Worlds. But in that game, they offered a choice to take extra perk points in exchange for your stats being lowered in specific ways. Like, taking too much head damage would make you 100 percent worse at aiming guns. It was an okay idea that felt too punishing and wasn‚Äôt much fun. In The Outer Worlds 2, the Flaw system has been revamped to add more chaos to a playthrough. Now, Flaws can be really wild and offer a mix of negative and positive effects. For example, in The Outer Worlds 2, if you steal a lot of items, the game will eventually detect this and offer you a Flaw that lets you sell stolen goods for double their value, but it also forces you to steal anything you get close to, which could cause some awkward moments in a store or town.

Flaws in Outer Worlds 2 can, if you desire, throw a wrench into your RPG experience and shake things up even dozens of hours into a playthrough. If you don‚Äôt look them up ahead of time, which you shouldn‚Äôt, they can spice up the latter half of the game, which can suffer from the same problem so many RPGs suffer from: letting you get stuck in a comfortable but boring rut.

How Flaws in The Outer Worlds 2 make it a better RPG

You know that point in an RPG where you‚Äôre nearing max level, have the weapons that work perfectly for your build, and have your skills dialed in. Fights become boring. Exploration isn‚Äôt as exciting either, as you‚Äôve been to most places a few times now. This is the point at which many players put down the game and walk away. Maybe you push through to wrap it up, having less fun as you go. But with Flaws, the final stretch of Outer Worlds 2 was still a wild time for me.

When I tried to speed through dialogue too much, I was offered a Flaw that would let me gain more XP, but would randomly choose options during dialogue. Another Flaw offered to make my melee strikes more deadly in exchange for taking more damage when I blocked, an offer which came after I spent too much time punching random baddies and not enough time blocking and dodging.

I didn‚Äôt accept all of them (and I definitely didn‚Äôt take the Flaw that makes you accept all Flaws moving forward), but just having such strange choices to contemplate 20+ hours into the game was fantastic. Each time a Flaw notification appeared, I perked up. And when I accepted one, like the Flaw that made me scared of mechs but able to do more damage to them, it altered my playthrough in a way I really appreciated and helped get me out of that ‚Äústuck in a rut‚Äù phase so many RPGs tend to end up in.

The only problem now is that when I started playing a different game, I found myself longing for silly, interesting, and possibly game-breaking flaws to appear as I played. It was a treat to have the game react to how I was playing, actively tempting me with ways to indulge in bad behaviors or silly habits (like reloading too much) in exchange for some equally silly punishments. Now I want more games to do that. So here‚Äôs me permitting RPG devs to steal Flaws from The Outer Worlds 2. I‚Äôd like that, please!
